dataset.title: Map of ecological sites and ecological states for pastures 1, 4, 14, and 15 on the Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Center, New Mexico

address.deliveryPoint: P.O. Box 30003; MSC 3JER New Mexico State University
P.O. Box 30003; MSC 3JER New Mexico State University
P.O. Box 30003; MSC 3JER New Mexico State University

abstract.para: This data package includes an ArcMap geodatabase for the Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Center (CDRRC) pastures 1, 4, 14, and 15: one polygon feature class, one point feature class, associated attribute tables and metadata. The spatial data, CDRRC1_4_14_15_StateMap_v1.gdb.zip, represents the ecological sites and states on Pastures 1, 4, 14 and 15 on the Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Center, and includes field traverse data. CDRRC1_4_14_15_StateMapMetadata.pdf and TraversePointsMetadata.pdf contain the geospatial metadata provided by ArcMap. CDRRC1_4_14_15_StateMap_v1.csv is the attribute table associated with the state map’s polygon feature class, and TraversePoints.xlsx is the attribute table associated with the traverse points feature class and includes a sheet containing detailed attribute metadata.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CDRRC Pastures 1, 4, 14, and 15: Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Center (CDRRC) Pastures 1, 4, 14, & 15

section.title: METHODS
section.para: To create this map, existing Soil Survey Geographic Database (SSURGO) soil map units were sub-divided based on imagery (2016 Digital Orthophoto Quarter Quads, DOQQ), knowledge of ecological site descriptions (ESDs) and state-and-transition models (STMs), existing spatial data layers, georeferenced ground data and field traverse data. Each child polygon was attributed with an ecological site and state code. A more detailed description of the state mapping process is described here: https://jornada.nmsu.edu/esd/state-mapping (accessed 6 Jan 2023).
Soil map units were obtained from the Dona Ana County Area, New Mexico (NM690) SSURGO Soil Survey: https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/App/WebSoilSurvey.aspx (accessed 6 Jan 2023).

The ecological site descriptions describing each ecological site, and associated states, are found on the Ecosystem Dynamics Interpretive Tool (EDIT): Ecological Site Descriptions for MLRA 042B (Southern Rio Grande Rift), LRU 42BB (Desert Shrub; R042BB***NM), are found at: https://edit.jornada.nmsu.edu/catalogs/esd/042B (accessed 6 Jan 2023).

Definitions of Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) and Land Resource Unit (LRU; accessed 6 Jan 2023): https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/resources/education-and-teaching-materials/defining-lrr-mlra-and-lru https://web.nmsu.edu/~hbw3/what-is-a-land-resource-unit.html

Descriptions of Major Land Resource Areas of the United States, and the MLRA Geographic Database, are available at: https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/resources/data-and-reports/major-land-resource-area-mlra (accessed 6 Jan 2023).

section.title: State Codes
section.para: State codes consist of two or three digits.
Two digit codes are as follows: 10 = exotic dominated 11 = Roads 12 = Tanks/Water hole 13 = Agricultural field.

Three digit codes are composed of the following: 1 = Grassland (HCPC state) 2 = Altered grassland / Altered savanna 3 = Shrub or Tree savanna (HCPC state) 4 = Shrub / Tree invaded grassland 5 = Shrub / Tree dominated 6 = Shrubland / Woodland 7 = Bare Annuals 8 = Gallery forest (HCPC state) 9 = Exotic invaded.

Three-digit codes represent the vegetation states in order of dominance. More than one code is used for a polygon where the polygon contains more than one vegetation state, and the patches are too small to delineate. The first code in the three-number sequence best describes the dominant state of the polygon. The second number represents the second-most common state. The last number represents the least common state. A zero is used for the second or third number when only one or two states are present.
State code example: 124 = reference grassland (1) is the dominant state; secondary state is altered grassland (2) and the polygon contains patches of shrub-invaded grassland (4).

project.title: Long-term research (LTER and LTAR) at Jornada Basin

section.para: The Jornada Basin is home to multiple long-term research networks, including the Jornada Experimental Range Long-Term Agroecosystems Research program (JER LTAR) and the Jornada Basin Long-Term Ecological Research program (JRN LTER). The JER LTAR program is part of a national network of long-term agricultural and rangeland ecology research sites funded by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). The Jornada Experimental Range is administered by the USDA-ARS (USDA Agricultural Research Service). JRN LTER is part of a national network of long-term ecological research sites funded by the US National Science Foundation (NSF). The JRN LTER program has been continuously funded since 1982 to develop general principles governing changes between grassland and shrubland ecosystems based on long-term data collected in the Chihuahuan Desert.

The JER LTAR program is supported by the USDA Long-Term Agroecosystem Research Network (CRIS# 3050-11210-009-00D). The JRN LTER program is funded by the National Science Foundation under award DEB 2025166.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique identifier for rows assigned by ArcGIS
NRCS soil survey soil map unit symbol
Soil Survey Geographic Database (SSURGO) soil survey area symbol

codeDefinition.definition: Dona Ana County Area, NM Soil Survey area symbol
MLRA code for the Southern Rio Grande Rift
LRU code for the Desert Shrub LRU of the Southern Rio Grande Rift MLRA

attribute.attributeDefinition: Dominant ecological site in the polygon, attributed by the state mapping technician

Second most common ecological site for the polygon, attributed by the state mapping technician. The 'second best fit' ecological site; used when there is uncertainty as to the ecological site or is the second dominant ecological site where more than one ecological site occurs within the polygon (e.g. undulating depth to petrocalcic horizon causing Shallow Sandy and Sandy ecological sites to vary over short distances).

Third most common ecological site for the polygon, attributed by the state mapping technician. The ‘third best fit’ ecological site; used when there is uncertainty as to the ecological site or is the third dominant ecological site where more than one ecological site occurs within the polygon.
Ecological state code attributed by the state mapping technician, consisting of two or three digits.
Remarks from the state mapping technician pertaining to the ecological site and/or state for a given polygon
Auto-populated by ArcGIS; length of the ecological state polygon
Auto-populated by ArcGIS; area of the ecological state polygon
